title: 111_hr2424
content: The Act may be cited as the "Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009". It includes findings related to the Federal Reserve. The Congress found that in August 2007, liquidity dried up in credit and securities markets, initially affecting financial firms with interests in mortgage-backed securities. This lack of access to credit spread globally, prompting the Federal Reserve to respond to the financial crisis. The Federal Reserve responded to the financial crisis by setting a target range for the Federal funds rate at 0 to 0.25 percent in December 2008, acknowledging the severity of the crisis and using its authority to address the situation. The Federal Reserve has acted in response to "unusual and exigent circumstances" multiple times since the financial crisis, extending assistance to nonmember institutions for the first time since 1959. The Federal Reserve extended assistance to nonmember institutions for the first time since 1959 and purchased debt obligations from government-sponsored enterprises for the first time since 1981 to address unusual circumstances. Additionally, joint programs with the Department of the Treasury were established to aid financial markets during the crisis. The Federal Reserve established joint programs with the Department of the Treasury to aid financial markets, including guaranteeing assets of Citigroup and Bank of America, the Term Asset-Backed Securities Lending Facility, and the Public-Private Partnership Investment Program. Chairman Ben Bernanke affirmed transparency commitment in a testimony to the Committee on Financial Services. SEC. 3. REVIEWS OF SPECIAL FEDERAL RESERVE CREDIT FACILITIES. Section 714 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General to conduct reviews of credit facilities established by the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System or any Federal reserve bank. This includes onsite examinations when deemed necessary. The Board or any Federal reserve bank can establish credit facilities for approved actions under the Federal Reserve Act as the lender of last resort or to provide temporary assistance to private institutions. The Federal Reserve Act allows the Board or any Federal reserve bank to establish credit facilities for approved actions, serving as the lender of last resort or providing temporary assistance to private institutions. The credit facilities covered under the Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 include the Money Market Investor Funding Facility, Asset-Backed Commercial Paper Money Market Mutual Fund Liquidity Facility, Term Asset-Backed Securities Loan Facility, Term Auction Facility, Primary Dealer Credit Facility, and Commercial Paper Funding Facility. The Federal Reserve Act authorizes credit facilities for approved actions, acting as a lender of last resort or providing temporary assistance to private institutions. The credit facilities covered under the Federal Reserve Credit Facility Review Act of 2009 include various programs such as the Term Securities Lending Facility, Maiden Lane LLC, Revolving Credit Facility, and Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program. The Federal Reserve Act authorizes credit facilities for approved actions, acting as a lender of last resort or providing temporary assistance to private institutions. These credit facilities include reciprocal currency arrangements with foreign central banks, Mortgage Backed Securities Purchase Program, and special purpose vehicles conducting lending activities. The authority for these actions will cease after a 5-year period from enactment. A report on each review conducted is required. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of completing each review conducted under paragraph (1). The report should include detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative action. The Comptroller General must submit a report to Congress within 90 days of completing each review, including detailed findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislative or administrative action. SEC. 4. ACCESS TO RECORDS. Access to Records.--Section 714(d)(1) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Comptroller General access to officers, employees, contractors, and other agents of any agency or credit facility established by an agency. The Comptroller General may request access at any reasonable time and make copies of records as needed. The Comptroller General may request and retain copies of records as deemed appropriate. Unauthorized access to records is amended to include copies of records and credit facilities established by an agency.
